children.name: unconventional c1
children.definition: unconventional very different from the way people usually behave, think, dress etc: khác thường
examples: his business methods were unconventional but successful.
her unconventional opinions finally cost her her job.
the two never lived in the same house, but their unconventional marriage lasted over 30 years.

children.name: alternative b2
children.definition: alternative alternative methods, ideas, ways of living etc are completely different from the ones that most people think are normal, and are based on different principles: khác thường
examples: alternative medicine/ lifestyle/ music etc
alternative medicine can cure many problems but not diseases like cancer
san francisco has a long history of accepting the city’s many alternative lifestyles.

children.name: unorthodox x
children.definition: unorthodox ideas, behaviour, or methods that are unorthodox are original and different from what is usual or the accepted principles of a profession, religion etc: không chính thống
examples: there was no tolerance of unorthodox political views.
treating the disease with a diet rather than with medicine is an unorthodox approach that few doctors recommend.

children.name: nonconformist x
children.definition: nonconformist not wanting to think or behave in the same way as most ordinary people, or to follow accepted ways of doing things: không khuôn phép
examples: as a writer he remained nonconformist all his life, always searching for new means of expression.
nonconformist[c noun]
she prided herself on being a nonconformist, on getting results by breaking the rules.
nonconformity[u noun]
her clothes were an immediate signal of her nonconformity.

children.name: drop out x
children.definition: drop out to decide not to work or take part in normal society because you want to be different and live life your own way: sống khác đi
examples: he advised young people to ‘turn on, tune in, and drop out’.
drop out of
she decided to drop out of the rat race because she couldn’t stand working 60 hours a week.
dropout/ drop-out[c noun]
he was a dropout and a hippy back in the '60s.

children.name: convention c1
children.definition: convention the rules and customs of acceptable behaviour, which are generally accepted by the members of a group or society: tục lệ, lệ thường, phép tắc thông thường
examples: he is a flamboyant millionaire who ignores social conventions.
conventiondictates thatit is the man who asks the woman to marry him and not the reverse.
in many countries, it is the/a convention to wear black at funerals.
convention of
she shocked her neighbours by ignoring every convention of respectable society.
a matter of convention
it is a matter of convention that male business people usually wear suits.
defy convention[do sth unconventional] bất chấp luật lệ
for the next four years they defied convention by living as man and wife when they were not.
theydefied/flouted/broke withconvention by giving up their jobs and becoming self-sufficient.

children.name: tradition b2
children.definition: tradition a belief, custom, or way of doing something that has existed for a very long time in a particular country or among a particular group of people: truyền thống
examples: a lot of the old traditions are dying out.
every village has its own traditions.
tradition of
the region has a tradition of winemaking which goes back to roman times.
tradition that
it’s still the tradition here that the eldest son inherits all the family’s money and land.
family tradition
we always go for a long walk on christmas morning - it’s a family tradition.

children.name: custom b1
children.definition: custom a way of behaving that has existed for a long time among a group of people, and is considered normal or polite - use this especially to talk about other countries or other times: phong tục tập quán
examples: sadly, a lot of the old customs are now dying out.
custom of
the custom of sending birthday cards began in the 19th century.
it is the custom (for sb) to do sth
it is the custom in japan to take your shoes off when you go into someone’s house.
in those days it was the custom for farmers to give part of their crop to the lord of the manor.

children.name: institution c2
children.definition: institution a custom, belief or way of doing sth that has become established and accepted as part of normal life among a particular group of people: quán lệ, thông lệ
examples: trading in ivory had become an institution in this part of africa
[figurative]mrs daly is an institution - she's been with the company 40 years and knows absolutely everyone.
institution of
church leaders are meeting this week to discuss ways of preserving the institution of marriage.

children.name: conformist x
children.definition: conformist thinking and behaving like everyone else, because you do not want to be different: tuân thủ, không phá cách phá lệ
examples: your problem is that you are too conformist in your thinking.
our children’s creativity is being beaten down by the conformist educational system.
conformist[c noun] [often disapproving] người tuân thủ
he’d never dream of trying something like that - he’s too much of a conformist.
conformity[u noun]
the system seems to value conformity over originality.
it's depressing how much conformity there is in such young children.

children.name: straight x
children.definition: straight informal conventional and often fairly boring: ngay thẳng
examples: paul’s quite nice but he’s awfully straight.
i can’t stand it when your friends come to visit - they’re so straight.

children.name: conservative c1
children.definition: conservative a conservative person is fairly old-fashioned in their attitudes, beliefs, styles of clothes etc, and does not like change or new ideas. old-fashioned attitudes, beliefs, styles etc can also be called conservative: bảo thủ
examples: june’s parents were very conservative and wouldn’t allow her to date till she was 18.
middle-aged men in conservative business suits
conservatively[adv]
she was in her mid-thirties, attractive, and conservatively dressed.

children.name: suburban x
children.definition: suburban especially uk typical of the attitudes and way of life of people who are conventional and ordinary, and who disapprove of anyone who does not live or behave like them: phong kiến
examples: she hated her parents’ suburban attitudes.
despite her suburban clothes and appearance she was popular at college.

children.name: conventional b2
children.definition: conventional conventional people, behaviour, and opinions are the type that most people in society think are normal and socially acceptable, although some people think they are boring and old-fashioned: thông thường, bình thường
examples: rosemary led a quiet, conventional life until she went to college.
her outrageous stage act is seen as a challenge to conventional morality.
acupuncture may work, but i still believe in a more conventional approach to medicine.
[disapproving]i find his art rather dull and conventional.
conventionally[adv] thông thường
she was dressed very conventionally in a dull grey suit.
dickinson was very spiritual but not conventionally religious.

children.name: traditional b1
children.definition: traditional doing things in a way that have existed for a long time, and not interested in anything new or different: truyền thống
examples: many traditional teachers still think of computers as useless toys.
his critics objected to the way he broke many of the traditional rules of art.

children.name: all the customs and beliefs of a country or group
tradition b2
children.definition: tradition all the beliefs and ways of behaving that have existed for a very long time in a particular country or among a particular group of people: truyền thống
examples: there is great respect for tradition among the older members of the community.
by tradition[according to a tradition] theo truyền thống
by tradition, it is the bride’s parents who pay for the wedding.

children.name: folklore x
children.definition: folklore old stories which the people in a country or area have told each other for a very long time, and which often contain historical or religious ideas: dân gian
examples: according to folkloretheo dân gian
according to folklore, king arthur will one day return to become king of britain.
in folklore: trong dân gian
in folklore the snake is often a symbol of evil.

children.name: heritage c2
children.definition: heritage art, literature, and traditions that are considered to belong as a right to all the people in a society, especially because they form an important part of a country’s history: di sản
examples: the town takes great pride in its architectural heritage.
these monuments are a vital part of theculturalheritage of south america.
national heritage
these works of art are considered of great importance to russia’s national heritage.
heritage of
the castle is part of the heritage of wales and should be preserved for the people of wales.

children.name: break with tradition b2
children.definition: break with tradition/ break with the past to stop doing things the way they have always been done in the past: không theo truyền thống, phá lệ
examples: the church has finally broken with tradition and allowed women into the ministry.
i think it’s time to break with the past and rewrite the constitution.
a break with tradition/a break with the past[np] when you stop doing things the way they have always been done in the past:
in a significant break with tradition, the queen will not attend this year’s ceremony.
political leaders are calling for a break with the past and a new spirit of cooperation.

children.name: go with the flow c2
children.definition: go with the flow to do what other people are doing or to agree with other people because it is the easiest thing to do
examples: just relax and go with the flow!

children.name: multicultural/multiracial
children.definition: /ˌmʌltiˈkʌltʃərəl◂, ˌmʌlti ˈreɪʃəl◂/  including or concerning people of different races or religions, especially those who live together in the same society, go to the same schools etc:đa văn hóa, đa chủng tộc
examples: ▪ most of today’s teachers are committed to multicultural education.
▪ he grew up in a multiracial area in london’s east end.
▪ government policies should reflect the multiracial nature of our society.

children.name: classical c2
children.definition: classical traditional in style or form, or based on methods developed over a long period of time : cổ điển kinh điển
examples: he is one of our greatest classical actors.
the classical theory of relativity
classical ballet/ dance etc
does she study classical ballet or modern ballet?

children.name: traditional b1
children.definition: traditional truyền thống
examples: belonging to the traditions of a country or group of people (use this about music, food, clothes, customs etc)
a group of children will perform traditional dances.
traditional african/ french/ english etc
the dancers were wearing traditional african costume.
the restaurant offers a wide range of traditional french food.
it is traditional to do sth
in the us it is traditional to dress up in costumes on halloween.
traditionally[adv] [b2]according to tradition; in a traditional way :theo truyền thống
a special dish that is traditionally eaten at new year
quaker meetings are traditionally held in silence.
traditionally, the company's main markets have been britain and the us.
traditionally sung[only passive]
god save the queen was traditionally sung on completion.

children.name: customary c1
children.definition: customary sth that is customary is considered normal or polite because it is the way it is usually done by a group of people: theo phong tục tập quán
examples: the man at the hotel welcomed us with the customary greeting.
it is customary (for sb) to do sth
it is customary for the man to propose to the woman.
